node.title: The Winter Solstice Approaches
node.description: Soon, the days will grow longer.
node.content: ["Welcome. The winter solstice in the Northern Hemisphere will occur next week, on Dec. 21. Here in New York, there will be just nine hours and 15 minutes of daylight on Tuesday, after which the days will begin to lengthen.", "Of course, the solstice is also the first day of winter, so even as the days grow longer, they tend to grow colder, too. I keep a close eye on sunrise and sunset after the solstice, greedy for those extra minutes of light, which, regardless of the temperature outside, promise that spring is on its way. My mother prefers the darker, shorter days, when it feels like bedtime at 5 p.m. She feels less pressure to be out and about and doing things.", "I understand this perspective, but the limited daylight, for me, sometimes means I don\u2019t make it outside while the sun is up. It contributes to that feeling that days and months are slipping by on a frictionless surface: I want to grab on to days and fill them, but I can\u2019t find a grip.", "I recently watched a YouTube video of Robin Pecknold, of the band Fleet Foxes, performing \u201cA Very Lonely Solstice\u201d \u2014 a show that was streamed live last December, from St. Ann & the Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn. Pecknold is good company for those of us who struggle with winter, who sometimes find ourselves white-knuckled inside our mittens, holding on for summer. It\u2019s mostly him strumming his guitar and singing quiet, wintry tunes by electric candlelight. \u201cOne warm day\u2019s all I really need,\u201d he sings at the end of \u201cFeatherweight.\u201d He\u2019s not the only one.", "We\u2019re still accepting submissions for your Best of 2021. Books, articles, movies, shows, recipes, ideas, routines, advice, you name it. Send them to athome@nytimes.com. Include your full name and location, if you please. We\u2019re At Home and Away. We\u2019ll read every letter sent. And of course, you\u2019ll find more ideas for passing the time pleasurably \u2014 wherever you find yourself \u2014 below. I\u2019ll be back on Friday.", "Were you forwarded this newsletter? Times subscribers can sign up here to receive it twice a week. There\u2019s more to read, do and watch in our archive. Let us know what you think."]
